you all know at this point what redshift is and really what we built it for was high performance data warehousing
that was easy to use and extremely cost effectively priced
and what we've seen as a result of this has been a real expansion in the number of use cases for which data warehousing can
now be used so it's not just traditional enterprise data warehousing we're also seeing a lot of big data
related use cases as well as sas applications where redshift is embedded under the scene
providing analytics to end customers
architecturally redshift is a clustered system it's got a leader node which is your sql
endpoint that's where you connect your applications and the leader node is really responsible for coordinating query
execution across the entire cluster everything's interconnected
your compute nodes which is where your data is stored and query processing takes place they're connected to the leader node and
to each other and to s3 using 10 gig e connections for high performance internode communication
and we also have a single node variant available where all of these are co-located to give you a low-cost
dev test environment and the pricing that you're looking at
here is for that single node price point this node has two terabytes of compressed storage on it
and we have three pricing models in an hourly pricing model it's under a dollar an hour which works out to an annual cost per
terabyte all in of just over thirty seven hundred dollars and then we have a one year
and three year reservation model where you can commit to those terms and get a forty percent or seventy
percent discount uh in return for doing that you're not charged for the leader node it's just
the number of compute nodes that you have in your system and the size of those nodes there's two sizes one at two t
and then the other one which is eight times larger at 16 terabytes per node and that is uh on an hourly basis eight
times the cost but because it has eight times the storage the cost per terabyte's the same

hi how's everyone doing i'm kevin diamond i'm the chief
technology officer for hautelook generally i talk at kind of e-commerce
and retail and fashion conventions so when i say hotlook everyone would know
what i'm talking about i assume probably for this crowd you might not have heard about
but that's okay i oversee all of our technology our infrastructure data
engineering so kind of everything falls under me but my major focus is on the customer
experience and how we prove that that's what the customer is actually experiencing
uh so i'll tell you quickly what outlook is we do private sale
kind of known as the members only limited time sale events it's all around premium
fashion lifestyle brands uh exclusive prices 50 to 75 percent off
every single day we do over 20 new sale events they all start at 8 a.m so we get kind
of the uh almost the black friday effect every single morning at that time
and we have over 14 million members and in 2011 we were acquired by nordstrom
so first off i want to talk about why a data warehouse so we have data in a lot of different
places and that's the common story when you're talking about building a data warehouse so we have our custom in-house
applications that were built on mysql all of those run on different servers
we have our erp platform our financial system that's running on ms sql
we run our own fulfillment centers so we have warehouse management systems those are running on ms sql
we also get data from all sorts of random sources whether it's itunes connect or wherever else and we wanted a place
where we could see all this data mesh it all together and be able to run analytics off of it so we knew we needed
a data warehouse but also we knew that we needed to put together a data model
around how you would look at this data and that was the bigger part of the challenge
because it's how do you look at kind of the operational reports versus the analytical reports
essentially the real time versus the previous day
so we looked at a bunch of competitors when we were trying to decide on who we were going to choose and uh you
know i as well didn't want to name names but uh we definitely saw
a huge difference in price when you start talking about redshift versus the other people in the marketplace but
even bigger was everyone else required us to buy software to do a big implementation to buy a ton
of hardware really big hardware put it in a data center pay for the power and the you know the
connectivity and all that kind of stuff and we didn't want to do any of that so we decided why even bother with the rfp
let's just go with them figure it out see whether it works so we jumped in the public beta and we
never looked back so for us the implementation has been
the the hardest part but that's because of our data so we built from from the ground up a
mysql database we didn't think about things like oh let's put a create date on a record you
know that might be helpful so the biggest piece was how do you do the etl out of mysql
on the microsoft side it was far easier because all those packages had that kind of
stuff engrained into it um but we ended up getting a direct connect line and we do kind of data
dumps on a daily basis right now into s3 those are
flat files so we do itunes connect our web analytics our log files
on top of all the other stuff that we do and then we used aws data pipeline
essentially we use scoop which is a apache project along with hadoop
we run that on ec2 and that loads all the data into the amazon redshift and kind of our data model around that
is kind of the star schema concept which if you're not familiar it looks something like this where you have facts
and dimensions
but obviously it's important to be able to actually look at what data you're storing so we chose a business intelligence tool
microstrategy they're a partner uh with uh amazon on this
uh we unfortunately had difficulty deploying them into the cloud uh that was half on us and uh
so we ended up just putting them on premise which is not ideal we hope to be able to move that uh later on but even having them on premise
and our data in the cloud it still works amazingly well and it was so easy to tie into amazon
redshift just using their odbc drivers um the way microstrategy works is it
kind of utilizes metadata all of that we had to put into an ms sql database hopefully in the future that can also live
in a place like redshift but we were able to get rid of all of our old legacy
ssis ssrs random mysql and excel reports that were all over the
place and move all of those that are based around the analytical reports into microstrategy
so this is kind of what it all looks like so we go from our our data center where
we have our mysql and our ms sql databases over a nice direct connect line and to our exported
data on to s3 the amazon data pipeline executes the jobs that run scoop and
hadoop on ec2 that processes the data to get it into the format that we actually want to see
it in and that's what loads it up into redshift and then we go across the internet back to our local servers where
we're running microstrategy and uh and to the local client's desktop
so we don't have a ton of data definitely not as much as that nasdaq is running on most of ours is
around the sale of goods so we have less than two terabytes
but at first we thought well hey let's go with the big 8xl it sounds cool they're awesome they're huge you know
to get great performance and so we spun up to uh kind of in a failover fashion uh
they are a little bit more costly uh granted as uh rahul mentioned that's uh you're
paying for what you get it does scale to the bigger size but for us we didn't really need that so we decided
hey let's run a comparison test of six xl instances and a cluster versus
essentially this one eight xl and we actually found that for majority of our queries it actually performed a
lot better but really that shouldn't have been
surprising for us because everything else we do is based on the cluster concept of how do you scale out
not scale up so really if you don't have the data if you don't need more than the two terabytes
that the xl instance offers definitely recommend going that route versus going up to the
big 16 terabyte eight xl instances
so for us uh the first hand experience etl was definitely our hardest part
but redshift has been performing great

and a big piece of that was hardware didn't have to spend a dollar of that so
i got to buy other cool stuff uh so there's no hardware cost there's no maintenance not the overhead

so in conclusion some advice only use the 8xl instances if you actually need

once you have reporting done you got to find those nuggets of opportunities i wish we had done this
here i wish we had com had this campaign run in this way you find those areas of optimization
and then you look at okay how can i make those recommendations so i can optimize so you have modeling solutions

so we receive as product said a number of different feeds from a number of different sources
we do a lot of work in getting those feeds into flat text files which we put onto s3
we use s3 as our file data store we keep the files on glacier in case
that we need to recover or reload them in any case we don't use redshift backups because
it's a tremendous amount of data with the files on s3 we load them on
predetermined schedules depending upon how we get them sometimes we get files every month sometimes we get them every week sometimes we get them every hour we
have got different jobs for every file they all get loaded through a pig script
to clean and format the data for loading into redshift the pig script does things such as validation ensuring
that number fields are numbers that we've got some sources that like to send them in exponential notation
which redshift won't take they need to be in a decimal format so we do all of that cleaning on hadoop
using pig we put the clean files back onto s3 then we load them into redshift using copy
statements this works incredibly well and is literally the simplest
etl job i have ever worked on
once in redshift we've got the data we've got it in the client's format we allow business analysts either inside
the front door chest bar inside the client themselves to connect to redshift using the vpc and
their you know bi tool of choice the popular one being tableau
this again solves another a number of problems for us without actually requiring any work besides setting up
the vpc if someone's analysts want to be running their own queries
it does not impact our performance noticeably and it makes them happy and everybody wins
in order to make the data useful for people who are not analysts and don't have tableau we aggregate it to
higher levels usually this is to a campaign level it depends on client they might want to track their marketing spending by
department or by campaign or by job or by brand
we have a lot of metadata gathered from the client that we also store in redshift we store it in redshift so
that we can easily run sql queries that join their client data against the metadata to produce
usable results for them
we have for each client we have a set of queries that will run through and will take
their data for a specific time period we'll join it using standard sql joins
to their metadata and output it into temporary tables which we will then write out to s3
we take those outputs written out through s3 through simple unload statements we load
them into our actual end result database which is mysql using mysql import and that
allows us to move on to the next step new side we do all of this using
a number of tools we use jenkins to do the job control when we need to schedule jobs so that imports run
every hour every day that is done through jenkins so that we're only notified on failure and we don't need to worry about it it
does email alerts in general if there's a problem it tends to be on the data side
that the client sent us bad data or you know some not our fault problem
ruby is the scripting language that we use to actually do the work you could go with anything we went with
ruby because our needs were relatively simple most of the work being done was
in sql in redshift we used dynamodb in order to do state storage for these
jobs so that we know which jobs are running how long they took various metrics such as that
finally with the the results of the client sql outputted
test three loaded into mysql that is what our actual website runs on the screenshots you saw
before of the scorecard application do not go against redshift directly because redshift
unfortunately does not provide response time which we need for
the website to be considered usable so we instead we pre-aggregate that data we
put it in my sql because in pre-aggregated form it is much smaller and then the website runs against mysql
we've got our clients going through we run our website using java on ec2 which is all within
aws the dns is done through aws it all works
really well so the reasons that we
and personally i love aws is that it allowed us to do all of this incredibly quickly i'm used to dealing
with other companies where having to do things such as saying up a huge you know 32 terabyte
cluster would take weeks all by itself without anything else
using redshift it was set up within a day and we were up and running with our proof of concept within two weeks
